The more and more my life has gone downhill, my mental sharpness has gone with it. I'm at the point where my college lectures are pointless because no matter how hard I try I'm lucky to retain 5% of the information, heck I can't even understand basic instructions anymore. And just like you my parents are super supportive of this mental illness, I get called numbskull, retard, or airhead all the time because I can't comprehend basic things.

Based on observation, adults from last generations who is not used to handling mental health issues with love ones will give you silence. Not because they hate you. But because they're unsure how to deal with it. 

It's never your fault, and yours feelings are valid. It's a good thing you have a sister who is concern with you and your well being. Take that as a win, and imagine how painful it is for your sister to know that you are hurting. 

Therapy will help, ask your sister to go with you. It will be a long journey, but love yourself because if you think your friends or family doesn't love you, that's not true. It's just that it's not the love that you were looking for. The love you are looking for is, the love for life which you have lost because of this mental illness. 

So try with all your energy left, if it makes you feel better post every day, every thoughts here in Reddit. You can do it. We believe in you. 🙏

And please don't say that you're a waste of oxygen. Every person matter in this world, every actions we decided on will affect another person around us. So it is up to us, how we continue breathing.

I'm 65 now and would like time to go back, but that's not how the universe works as you probably already know. I spent the past 50 years full of regrets, but along the way I was a caregiver for 3 different quite elderly people and knew them all well. Aging is rough on everyone, not just you and me. I suddenly have a gut I never had for the past 60 years, but here it is and there's not much I can do about it except to buy different clothes and avoid mirrors when showering. 
You, me and everyone else have the rest of our lives ahead of us and our pasts are done and over with. There is no going back, just the future and right now. I can't change a single regret about much of anything, but I can control how I react with the future and the thing is I'm closer to dying of old age than at any point in my entire life and it'll be true tomorrow and the day after that and the day after that and so on. It's taken me awhile, but I no longer dwell on my past. I wouldn't even want to be as stupid as I was at 20 and I did WAY MORE than my share of stupid back then and kept doing it well into my 50's.. I'm finally to the point of being able to take absolutely guilt free naps every afternoon. Sleep is good for you. It's even better at 65.. 
Good luck!

Depression will cause a bit of cognitive impairment, but it's typically not permanent when you're young. I'm 65 and have had several episodes of severe depression over the years and at times felt dumber than ditch water, but it's usually transitory.. At my age there's lots of things I no longer remember and I don't concentrate nearly as well as years past, but it's kind of to be expected at my age.  The best I can tell you is the immortal words of my old man, "Wait'll you get to be my age!" He lived to 92..

That's brain fog, you're definitely not alone. That and fatigue are my worst symptoms these days (technically I have bipolar but I mostly get depression episodes). I try to wake up my brain a little bit by watching documentaries because it doesn't take much effort and I can find a documentary about literally anything. But I'm also still not able to work, this just makes it so that I can think straight enough to keep my house clean. Sometimes doing any sort of activity can help boost your thinking, even walking around your room and reading every word you see. Anything that makes your brain work that you can still handle. But sometimes you can't handle even that. It really does suck, it's like a giant brick wall put up on every side of you that blocks you from taking a single step forward.

Relatable, I have almost nothing of what I would have expected by my age (30's) and worse, my dream is dead because there's never going to be a situation where I can go and get my bachelor's or master's degree, I simply can't afford it and I'm unemployable so I refuse to sign myself up for a school loan that I could never pay back.

I have so little to be happy about, I do my best to remain optimistic, but sometimes I fall into a chasm, like today, and it seems like there's no way to climb out so I am forced to walk forward till it ends.

Medications are a crapshoot for me because none of them seem to help for long. My psych refuses to prescribe me anything stronger, I'm sure because of the potential for abuse, but I just want to feel alright.

So I feel you, from someone who is going nowhere fast, I hope you feel better soon. Good luck.

This makes complete sense. 

I literally thought this morning: life is WORSE than a prison because we don’t know WHY we are being punished. Imagine waking up in a prison cell, and you don’t know what you did to be there. You ask the guards, and they just smile blankly at you, telling you nothing. 

I feel you, and the hardest part for me is that other people’s words don’t really help. I mean when they sympathize. I need solutions, goddamit! 😅 but also, what can they say? And what can I say to you? I can say I 1000% (I rarely exaggerate percentages) get you. The unfairness is the worst of it. As you say, some people just avoid trouble whereas it seems to follow me (at least). I feel like my life has been a shield to my sister. My gravity has sucked in all the bad debris while her life glides along. I know it’s just perception, but I’ve been through years of bullying, parental alienation (I do now see my adult son), financial shocks (property sold behind my back), lots of really twisted stuff. 

Onto your weekly setup, what do you do when your kids are with your ex? I feel like that’s a key time to find some kind of light at the end of the tunnel. Exercise has been a great help to me over the years.

Are you still looking for work? Is that part of why you’re in a hole mentally now? (Fully understandable). Having a project to work on has helped focus my mind and get me off the treadmill of negativity for a while. 

Sometimes though, it’s especially bad, like it sounds with you now. Honestly, all I can do is weather the storm. I’ve had all-nighters where my mind is spinning. I just have to sit in the pain and wait it out. The only way to 'fix' social anxiety is to interact with people which is why social anxiety is so hard to deal with. There is no easy fix to loneliness with social anxiety, you just have to try to work on it through interacting with people. Gradual exposure is a good start, try putting yourself in situations that give you a little anxiety and have little consequence (for example saying hi to a cashier) and work your way up in small increments, the only way this will ever be solved is through interaction. I know from personal experience how hard social anxiety is to deal with but the only solution to your problem is to gradually face your anxiety. You just have to try, which is easier said than done, but will leave you with less regret.

About getting somewhere, life has 2 dimensions.

The first is survival, you have to survive to live. When it comes to this dimension, "getting somewhere" is applicable. This is a logical dimension, it has steps, it has degrees, progression is possible. This is like school, you progress from grade to grade. Or like science, you need to make the basic discoveries first, then you make the more complex one's. There's clear progress, you're "getting somewhere".

The second is life itself. You've secured your survival, your existence, now it's time to exist! Most people don't reach this dimension, they stop at survival and remain there for their entire lives. That is why they never become happy, because they never live, just survive.

In this dimension, there's no progress, because this is not a logical dimension. If we have to make a supposition since I mentioned logic previously, this is the dimension of emotion. Emotion is sudden, it can just happen at any time, no steps, no progress, just BOOM and it's there.

If survival is science, then life is music, art. The goal in music is not to play the fastest song, it is not to reach the end of the song the quickest, or to compose the song the quickest. The goal is the song itself and there is nothing beyond that. In dance, the goal is to dance, there's nothing beyond that. You're not looking for the fastest dancer, you're not looking to end the dance at a particular spot on the floor, that is irrelevant. The dance is all there is, the dance is everything and there is nothing beyond it. It serves no purpose and it has no conclusion or criteria.

The same goes for love, there's no goal beyond it, there's no progression in it. You either love or you do not love. if you're in love, then there's no progression and no goal beyond love, you just love! And there's no need for a goal or something beyond, just being in it is a great bliss. No need to do anything or go anywhere, just being in it is all there is.

You're a kid and you're still learning about the world and how things work. You're bound to make mistakes and that's OK. It's normal, everyone makes mistakes. The hard part is regulating your emotions (I'm an adult and I still struggle with it myself). Things do get better as you get older since you have more control of your life and can seek help without permission.

I know you're a teenager, so it's hard to fix any of your situation by yourself. For now, talking about how you feel probably is the best option. Writing in a journal could be helpful to express yourself in a healthy way. 

One thing that might be helpful is by making a list of things you like or make you happy. Start with 1 item and then add 1 more every day. Maybe start with your cat or a family member, or a friend and then keep working on adding things. 

Additionally, you can start making a plan. For instance, "I want to move out when I'm 18." Then you can go from there and say, "I want to live in X country/state/province/city." Setting goals and then checking them off can be very helpful. You can list where you want to work in the future. Maybe you want to become a pilot? Maybe you want to go to space? Take some time to think about what's important to you. If you can't pick one thing, that's fine pick several. If you had unlimited money, what would you do with it? I hope this helps and sorry for the long post.

Your post hits hard, I’m a similar age to you and struggling in college. Right now I’m 2 weeks behind in my most important subject with an exam next week and I’m probably going to get no sleep soon, again. It’s a very vicious cycle. I also have panic attacks and this stress is ruining mental and physical health. From online binging I’ve found some good tips, but take them with a grain of salt since it’s coming from me.

I think the best approach to this type of anxious behavior is to approach self-improvement from the lens of self-compassion and care. I know it sounds generic but at least from my experience, I always criticize and beat myself up everyday for my actions. I act like a drill instructor to myself, I self-flagellate and pressure myself to get good habits. I verbally and physically abuse myself everyday. Then I asked, why am I doing this to myself? Even if I am really pathetic and inept, why do I keep kicking a dead horse? 

I know it’s hard because a lot of depression and anxiety comes from some form of self-hatred, so I think one of the first steps is to change that mental dialogue. 

And to be clear, self-care is not the same as putting important things off to self-soothe with the internet or whatever. In fact, I think we develop a lot of feel-good behaviors that are actually indirect self-harm and self-sabotage. It’s more akin to a smoker quitting cigarettes, even if the cigarettes feel good. That is true self-compassion for your body and mind. If I’m feeling really bad on a particular day I like to take a shower and make some hot tea to get back to reality a little bit, and go from there. 

I think the goal is to develop our inner thoughts as an inner “friend,” something that provides compassion and accountability. I hope your situation gets better man. Idk if this helped at all and it might not solve everything, but know you’re not alone in this brother.

But it happened ages ago. The furniture was in a guest bedroom so it wasn’t like she took the bed he was sleeping on that night. Also I never knew if there may of been some conversation between them way before it even happened. Like suggesting she could have the furniture someday when she got a place of her own. Dad called the Sheriff on her to try to get the furniture back and press charges. I don’t know for sure if he ever followed through with either of the two because it was so long ago and he never discusses it. She moved out of the area to start her life back then after that happened. Dad still did not want anything to do with her. He took all her pictures out of a family photo frame collage on the wall and left empty brown cardboard spaces. Everytime visiting him was the gut wrenching sadness to see that hanging on the dining room wall every time I went to visit him. 

Occasionally would bring up we really should all four try at least to be together as a family even if it was just on Thanksgiving or Christmas. Eggshells conversation every time. He would just get so angry we couldn’t talk about it without regretting coming to see him. Trying to get him to see how his stupid his grudge was with his oldest daughter was destroying any possibility of knowing each other together as a family. Letting years tick by from kids to adults with our lives and people getting married and kids being born.. A stupid grudge over bedroom furniture for whatever reason he never let it go. 

Eventually I had to stop seeing him for my own mental health. I think it was about 2017 since I’ve last seen him. He would bring up anger about other general things in life and it started  to be a negative hit just trying to spend time with him. He wasn’t all bad but the negativity side I couldn’t handle just trying to see how he was and especially directed towards my older sister just trying to discuss the possibility of time together when it happened so long ago.

He eventually had to see my older of the two sisters his daughter at the celebration of life which as stated I didnt even know about it.. My dad, cousins family never said a word about it was happening to me and clearly could have send a social media message of they at least need me to contact them it’s important and urgent. It was filmed by the funeral services thankfully and was able to watch it on my iPad about a month and a half after it happened. In the video he walked up behind to talk to my sister he had grudge with after it was over and the situation was really difficult for her. As he was walking up to her with her high school aged son and burly looking husband sitting near her. He walked over around the mic podium and right past his grandson. Which he is around 14-15 losing his mother.. I so get this and have asked myself the same thing many times.  I’m so sick of the cycle. 

A general thing to make life easier& make the ‘bad times’ less horrible and guilt filled.
I write my ‘healthy self’ (in my journal) about how bad I feel and stuff she (future me) can do to make life more tolerable.
Because in general my ‘depressed self’ hated my ‘healthy self’ because she was making the commitments.  So my ‘healthy self’ is now more careful. Agrees to far less.  That way, when I start to slide into depression, there’s less to get overwhelmed by (less commitments to have to get out if).

And in the ‘good times’ life has been far less about making money and having vacations, etc.  It’s more about having good relationships.  Because those things are what make life worth getting-through… that in some small ways I’ve made others lives better.

This is like what OP is talking about. We don't have the same patterns that people without depression have. Normal people gain happiness and feel naturally comfortable from being outside and socializing. Depressed and/or anxious people feel drained, unhappy, and mentally depleted from it. It's not something you just solve from doing it a bunch of times. It's not like learning to ride a bike (something people sadly compare it to) where you get better the more you do it. It's instead like trying to ride a bike without legs. 

I leave the house and socialize every day because of work but I don't enjoy it or feel pleasure from it. The issue is much deeper than just doing it a bunch of times and hoping it gets better.

interesting how the most honest comment got downvoted. As someone who has experienced it firsthand, sibling grief is the worst. The feeling never truly goes away—it constantly shifts from one stage to another. Parents may either be indifferent towards you or become hyper-vigilant, depending on which child they prioritize more. Or they may push you away. 

Meanwhile, your sister formed a trauma bond with the place where she stayed, as it became intertwined with the memory of losing her sibling. Everything about that place reminds her of her brother’s loss. Thoughts like " why, why, why I wanted to live in that apt?! " place would automatically repeats in her mind  nonstop for about a year. That eventually could havoc her decision making in the future on anything and everything 

Possibly, in moments of anger, your parents might even question why she had to live on the 22nd floor, she may receive a message like " so now you happy you wanted to live there?! " maybe months or years after your passing.  

Now think about these couple examples, multiple by 100. 

Back to you—I genuinely feel bad for you. Depression is awful, and absolute hopelessness is often known as the “dark night of the soul.” I’ve experienced both. But do you know what’s worse than those two? The possibility of having a terminal illness. Strangely, both terminal illness and suicide lead to the same end, yet they feel entirely different. Maybe, with suicide, we feel we’re in control. 

So whats happening in your life so bad that you don't feel in control?

I’m on the other end of this and can tell you how it can feel for us. When we love you, we want to do anything we can to support you but just don’t know how to help. Seriously we’re clueless unless we also have depression. And it hurts us when you don’t respond IF we’re unaware of how isolating works. But when we understand, then it doesn’t hurt us. It took me a lot of research and Reddit and Quora threads on this exact subject to finally get it enough to be a good support. My tips for you are:

1. Just let them know it’s normal for depression to cause the need to isolate and it’s nothing personal to them. You’re not mad at them. It really helped me when I learned how even texting just one text can feel overwhelming. Tell them this.
2. If you can, try to let them know when they’re texting too much or if you’re appreciating the amount their giving. We get so worried that we’re smothering you or not checking in enough so it’s a huge relief if you tell us what you like. Be honest. If you like daily contact, weekly, monthly, etc, or none at all, let them know.  We WANT to give you what you want and need.

If you’re the friend of a depressed person, read as many threads on Quora and Reddit as you can. It’s your responsibility to familiarize yourself with depression as much as possible because they just don’t have the energy to teach you. From everything I read most depressed people love when you check in on them often and want you to know they probably won’t respond but they’ll appreciate you anyway even if they can’t show it. 

I’ve noticed that it changes from day to day too. They may have a good day and actually be chatty or even want to see you (something low-key like taking a walk) and other days they will just stare at their phone listening to your texts or calls come through but not able to move. They will usually read or listen to them later though but probably won’t respond because it could be days later.  I will often leave a voice message so they can listen to it back over and over again whereas texts can end up being too far up to scroll back.

Another good thing is to send a short video clip telling them a story about your day or just saying hi. I send my girlfriend video clips almost every day and she likes them a lot better than text, which is difficult to read sometimes.

Also, don’t take it personally if they are forgetful or seem out of it. They literally can have a hard time just thinking. And don’t expect them to make decisions. Avoid asking questions if you can. Just let them know you care and you’re there for them if they need anything. 

And let them know how much you care and what you love about them. Depression tells them they’re unworthy of love and that they’re bad. Counter that by telling them if you think they are sweet soul or loving person or whatever is true for you. And let them know it’s okay for them to not respond to your reach outs.

Yes, it can also get worse again at times, but I think as you get older you learn what works and what doesn't, and you get more and more "good" and less and less "bad." I think the learning curve is different for everyone, but I think 25ish is probably the average where you start realizing "Oh huh, I guess it can just start being more better than worse."

I'm not saying there aren't moments where things don't get bad, where you feel like you can't handle one more day. But it's a lot easier once you've had the good ones too and see the pattern starts erring more and more in the direction of good, on an exponential level.

Think about the ratio of good days versus bad days at say age 20 vs 25 vs 30, etc. I think most people with depression would agree that ratio skews to more good the higher the age.

"Depression is not due to your lack of anything,
But because you’ve held onto too much pressure in your mind.
You are not as bad in reality as you imagine.
Don’t let anyone insult or manipulate your beliefs.
Let the bad people be; ignore the wicked society,
You live your own life, after all.
If you hate someone, don’t act like them.
If you dislike society, don’t live by its rules.
Don’t assume everyone is bad; look back at yourself first.
Leave behind the people and places you hate.

Who has told you that you're weird? People at school? When you were in kindergarten, did you think you were "weird"? Maybe, but probably not.

That's something someone has told you. Whether it was the media, other people, family, anything. And feeling like an outcast can sap your motivation real quick. What's the point of doing anything when you feel so different? 

But you're not weird. You should be accepted fully and unconditionally as your authentic self. Every human deserves that. Our anger, our joys, our interests, our passions... someone should unconditionally accept us (but not totally take our bullshit) for who we are. 

Keep looking for kin spirits. You'll find 100 people who don't fit your vibe, but that 101st one just might. It takes time to find people you feel that spark with. 

There a shit ton of people in the world. There's got to be a group out there for you to match your weirdness. 

Source: I'm crazy as hell.
